title: Crested Gecko Feeding Guide: Complete Nutrition by Life Stage
description: Comprehensive feeding guide for crested geckos covering age-based diets, crested gecko diet powder, feeder insects, supplementation schedules, and body condition assessment.
author: Habitat Builder

content.title: Complete Nutritional Guide for Crested Geckos
content.content: Crested geckos are omnivores that consume both fruit and insects in the wild. In captivity, they thrive on specially-formulated crested gecko diet (CGD) powder supplemented with live feeder insects. CGD is a nutritionally-complete meal replacement that becomes a smoothie when mixed with water, eliminating the need for complex fruit preparation. This guide covers evidence-based feeding protocols for optimal crested gecko health.
Nutritional needs change dramatically as crested geckos grow. Hatchlings need frequent, calorie-dense meals for rapid growth, while adults require less frequent feeding to prevent obesity.

content.text: Feeding Schedule by Age:

content.content: Overfeeding adults is a common mistake that leads to obesity, fatty liver disease, and shortened lifespan. Adults should have visible hip bones and a tail that is no wider than their neck. If your adult gecko's tail is wider than their head, reduce feeding frequency.
CGD powder is a revolutionary product that transformed crested gecko keeping. It's nutritionally complete—no fruits, vegetables, or vitamin dusting required when CGD is the primary diet.

content.text: Recommended CGD Brands:

rows: Most popular, excellent palatability, complete nutrition
Original CGD brand, time-tested, comprehensive formulation
Designed for New Caledonian geckos, premium ingredients

content.content: Variety is key—rotate 2-3 different CGD brands/flavors to provide nutritional diversity and prevent boredom. Many keepers mix brands in the same feeding to combine nutritional benefits.
Proper CGD mixing is essential for palatability and nutrition. Too thick and geckos can't lick it efficiently; too thin and nutritional density drops.

content.text: CGD Mixing Guidelines:

rows: Thin applesauce (easier to lick for small tongues)
Ketchup consistency (should hold shape but flow slowly)

content.text: CGD Feeding Protocol:

rows: Mix powder + water in small cup or ledge
Mix immediately before feeding (evening, around 7-9 PM)
Magnetic ledge, gecko feeding cup, or cork bark
Mid to upper level, easily accessible from vines
Discard any uneaten CGD from prior feeding
CGD spoils in 24 hours—never leave more than one night
Crested geckos are most active 8 PM-4 AM
Check if gecko licked cup clean or left residue
Adjust portion size based on consumption patterns

content.content: Mix CGD fresh for each feeding—don't pre-mix and refrigerate. Refrigeration changes texture and reduces palatability. Unused dry powder lasts 6-12 months sealed in a cool, dry place.
While CGD is nutritionally complete, live insects provide enrichment, stimulate hunting behaviors, and add protein variety. Size insects appropriately to prevent choking.

content.text: Best Feeder Insects:

rows: Rare treat only (2x per month max)

content.content: NEVER feed insects wider than the space between your gecko's eyes. Oversized insects cause impaction, choking, or regurgitation. For dubias/roaches, use 1/2 width rule—they're bulkier than crickets of similar length.
Overfeeding insects (especially to adults) leads to obesity and CGD refusal. Use conservative portions to maintain diet balance.

content.text: Insect Quantities per Feeding:

rows: 1x per week (some keepers do every 10-14 days)

content.content: Insects are enrichment, not the primary diet. CGD should provide 70-80% of calories for adults. If your gecko refuses CGD and only wants insects, reduce insect frequency to every 10-14 days until they resume eating CGD.
CGD is already vitamin/mineral fortified. Insect supplementation depends on whether you provide UVB lighting.

content.text: Supplement Protocol by Setup:

rows: Calcium WITHOUT D3 (Arcadia CalciumPro Mg, MinerAll Outdoor)
Calcium WITH D3 (Zoo Med Repti Calcium + D3, Repashy Calcium Plus)
Dust insects lightly every feeding OR every other feeding

content.content: Do NOT dust CGD with calcium powder—it's already fortified and over-supplementation can cause organ damage. Only dust insects. Use light dusting ("shake and bake" method in cup)—insects should look lightly frosted, not caked white.
Gut-loading (feeding insects nutritious foods before offering to your gecko) passes nutrition through the insect to your pet.

content.text: Gut-Loading Protocol:

rows: Leafy greens, squash, commercial cricket diet
Carrots, sweet potato, Repashy Bug Burger, greens
Avoid: spinach, lettuce (poor nutrition), citrus (too acidic)

content.content: Commercial gut-load diets (Repashy Bug Burger, Cricket Crack, Fluker's High Calcium Cricket Diet) are convenient and nutritionally optimized. DIY gut-loading with fresh vegetables works but requires variety and avoidance of low-nutrient items like iceberg lettuce.
CGD contains significant moisture (60-70% water when mixed) and contributes to hydration. However, it doesn't replace proper misting and humidity management.

content.text: Dietary Water Sources:

rows: Primary dietary water source, provides moisture + nutrients
Not needed—CGD already contains fruit, fresh fruit upsets gut flora
Some geckos drink standing water, but most rely on droplets/CGD

content.content: Do NOT offer fresh fruit (mango, banana, etc.) to crested geckos. CGD already contains fruit in optimal ratios. Fresh fruit ferments quickly, disrupts gut bacteria, and can cause diarrhea. Stick to CGD for fruit nutrition.
Regular body condition scoring helps adjust feeding frequency to prevent obesity or underfeeding.

content.text: Body Condition Scoring:

rows: Hip bones very prominent, tail narrow, ribs visible, sunken eyes
Increase CGD to daily + insects 2-3x/week until weight improves
Tail plump but not wider than neck, hip bones barely visible, active
Hip bones slightly visible, tail rounded but not bulbous, active
Maintain current schedule—CGD every 2-3 days, insects 1x/week
No hip bones visible, tail wider than head, fat deposits in armpits/neck
Reduce CGD to every 3-4 days, insects every 10-14 days
Severe fat deposits, tail 2x width of head, lethargic, labored breathing
Vet consultation—possible fatty liver disease, reduce feeding drastically

content.content: Weigh your crested gecko monthly using a digital gram scale (accurate to 0.1g). Adults should maintain stable weight (35-50g depending on genetics). Weight loss of 10%+ in one month requires vet evaluation.

content.text: Mistakes to Avoid:

rows: Nutritional deficiencies, calcium deficiency, metabolic bone disease
CGD must be primary diet (70-80% of intake), insects are supplemental
Obesity, fatty liver disease, shortened lifespan (10 years vs 20)
Feed adults every 2-3 days, NOT daily—they don't need constant food
Remove uneaten CGD after 24 hours, mix fresh each feeding
Diarrhea, gut flora disruption, CGD refusal
No fresh fruit—CGD contains optimal fruit nutrition already
Light dusting only—insects should be lightly frosted, not caked
Using baby food instead of CGD
Incomplete nutrition, lacks insects/protein, vitamin deficiencies
Only use CGD formulated for crested geckos—baby food is not nutritionally adequate
Insect width ≤ space between gecko's eyes (or 1/2 for bulky roaches)

content.content: Where and how you present food affects feeding success and enclosure hygiene.

content.text: Food Presentation Options:

rows: Easy access, stable, easy to remove for cleaning
Secure attachment, contains mess, dishwasher safe
Need to climb into cup (ensure accessibility)
CGD can spill into substrate if not level
Hard to control portions, insects may hide

content.content: Position feeding ledges mid to upper level of enclosure—crested geckos feel safer eating off the ground. Have 2-3 ledges/cups so you can rotate (one in use, one being cleaned).

content.text: Common Problems and Solutions:

rows: Reduce insect frequency to every 10-14 days, try different CGD flavors
Won't eat after moving to new home
Normal for 1-2 weeks, ensure temps/humidity correct, minimize handling
Monitor weight—if stable, this is normal behavior (reduce feeding frequency)
Sudden appetite loss (any age) + weight loss
Vet visit required—check fecal for parasites, verify temperatures
Food too large, temps too low, illness
Reduce insect size, verify basking area 82-85°F, vet check if continues
Only licks CGD, doesn't consume much
Add more water to thin consistency—should flow slowly, not be paste-like

content.text: Essential Feeding Supplies:

rows: 8-16 oz jars last 2-4 months per gecko
With or without D3 (based on UVB setup)
Magnetic ledges or suction cup feeding cups

content.content: Monthly feeding cost: $15-25 (CGD powder $8-15, insects $5-10, supplements $1-2 amortized). Crested geckos are one of the most affordable reptiles to feed due to CGD's convenience and nutritional completeness.
